It looks at the application, sees any new dependencies or commands or whatever the case is, and updates anything that it deems important to add back to that markdown file. And it's just nice if you have a repo that has a lot of development, a lot of people working in it, and you don't always want to... capture every single new like merge or rebase like every other day to it so maybe your brew updates running that like the repo refresh like once a week or something like that would be good because then you don't have to type out like oh rescan the repo and do this and that and the other thing like now this will just take care of it so that was i think the first one that i made so that one's been really helpful refreshing everything because the first time i ran it it picked up like i think i last time i refreshed it was i don't know three four weeks ago so i found like a whole bunch more stuff it updated like architecture changes like a whole whole bunch of things uh to it so that's been really helpful probably gonna run that like on a weekly basis now on all the repos that we're working on.
